name: 2-methyl-2-butanol production | 2-methyl-2-butanol | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4863/documentation

This data represents the production of 1 kg of pure 2-methyl-2-butanol via the hydration of 2-methyl-2-butene.;2-methyl-2-butanol (CAS-No. 75-85-4, C5H11OH, Synonym: tert-amyl alcohol, tert-pentanol) is a colourless;liquid of characteristic odor. It is only sparingly miscible with water at 20 °C. However, it is;almost completely miscible with most organic solvents.;2-methyl-2-butanol is employed as solvent for coating materials based on epoxy resins and polyurethanes,;in the production of aryl pyruvic acids, and in the oxidation of olefins to the corresponding;carbonyl compounds. It is also used as a stabilizing agent for 1,1,1-trichloroethane, chlorinated C3 –;C4-hydrocarbons, and N,N,- dialkylallyl amines. The reaction of 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-4-cyano-4-;hydroxypiperidine with 2-methyl-2-butanol yields highly active light stabilizers for polymers.;In this dataset, the raw material inputs, and process-specific material exchanges, are modelled with a generic stoichiometry-based tool, using literature or estimated yields. The emissions are modelled with a default value, which is estimated  based on losses, unreacted chemicals, among others. At the same time, the energy consumption is based on data from literature sources.  Finally, the auxiliary (i.e., cooling water and infrastructure) exchanges are modelled with a default value based on industry data from literature sources.   For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;;References:;Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Heck T.,;Hellweg S., Hischier R., Nemecek T., Rebitzer G. and Spielmann M. (2007);Overview and Methodology. Final report ecoinvent v2.0 No. 1. Swiss Centre for;Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.org.;Lappe, P., Hoffmann, T.: Pentanols. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial;Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann;G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition.;Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under:;http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/ueic/articles

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

The activity ends with 2-methyl-2-butanol being ready for further transformation or transportation at the production site gate. Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period spans from the earliest year from which at least one of the input values was obtained until 2022, but overall form the most realistic picture of the production. Besides, the activity is partly generated, in terms of material inputs and outputs, based on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields, which does not expect to change over time.;The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 1989) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. The end time period is therefore set based on the years from Gendorf reference.;For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure and in the comments of the exchanges.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled at the Global level. The main material inputs and outputs of this activity are generated with on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields.  Furthermore, the source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure. ;The dataset could also be considered as not geography-specific, and thus, valid for a broader geographical coverage.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Kim, Seungdo, and Michael Overcash "Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate‐to‐gate information for life cycle assessment." Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology: International Research in Process, Environmental & Clean Technology 78.9 (2003): 995-1005.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset covers the production of 2-methyl-2-butanol by the hydration of 2-methyl-2-butene (isopentene).;Only a few industrial processes are known for the production of pentanols, namely, hydroformylation of butenes, hydrolysis of chloropentanes, and hydration of pentenes. Production of C5-alcohols from fusel oils by fermentation has been replaced mainly by the oxo synthesis and currently has little industrial importance. Production of pentanols from pentane by the Sharples process (chlorination of pentanes and subsequent hydrolysis) has also been largely replaced by oxo synthesis.;Hydration of pentenes;2-methyl-2-butanol is produced mainly by hydration of 2-methyl-2-butene (isopentene). There are;several processes which use different catalysts, e. g. acid ion exchangers, zeolites, layer silicates, formic;acid, HCl, SbCl3, ZnCl2, or acetic acid.;Reaction:;C5H10 + H2O --> C5H12O;As there was no data available for the production of 2-methyl-2-butanol, the values for the consumption of the raw materials are calculated with an assumed yield of 95 % (Frischknecht et al. 2007). At the same time, the values for the energy use have been estimated with data from Chauvel 1989, who gives data for the production of isopropanol from the hydration of isopropylene. Hence, this process is considered to be similar to the hydration of 2-methyl-2-butene.;Reference:;Lappe, P., Hoffmann, T.: Pentanols. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossman G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/ueic/articles;Chauvel, A., Lefebvre, G.: Petrochemical processes. Vol 2: Major oxygenated,;chlorinated, and nitrated derivatives. Institut français du pétrole publications.;Éditions Technip, Paris 1989;Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Heck T.,;Hellweg S., Hischier R., Nemecek T., Rebitzer G. and Spielmann M. (2007);Overview and Methodology. Final report ecoinvent v2.0 No. 1. Swiss Centre for;Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.org.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Literature data and stoichiometric calculation. This inventory is partially based on a generic model of the production of chemicals. The data generated by this model have been improved with compound-specific data when available. The model of the production of chemicals is using specific industry or literature data wherever possible and more generic data on chemical production processes to fill compound-specific data gaps when necessary. The basic principles of the model have been published in literature (Hischier, 2005). The model has been updated and extended with newly available data from the chemical industry. In the model, unreacted fractions are treated in a waste treatment process, and emissions reported are after a waste treatment process that is included in the scope of this dataset. For volatile reactants, a small level of evaporation is assumed. Solvents and catalysts are mostly recycled in closed-loop systems within the scope of the dataset and reported flows are for losses from this system.
The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 1989) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, and chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information refer to the comments of the exchanges.

References:
Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit 
Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average ouput of wastewater going to an external wastewater treatment plant in the years 2015-2019 was 5608 m3 per year. This equals 0.000002277 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description: This value is estimated based on the heating requirements of a similar process. Specifically, this value represents the direct hydration of isopropanol, which was reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989). The value of electricity input for the latter process is 0.09 kWh per kg. All in all, we assume that the electricity requirements for the hydration of isopropylene, based on a Deutsche Texaco process, and 2-methyl-2-butene are similar.

exchanges.description:
This value is estimated based on the cooling requirements of a similar process. Specifically, this value represents the direct hydration of isopropanol, which was reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989). The value of cooling water input for the latter process is 0.19 m3 per kg. All in all, we assume that the cooling requirements for the hydration of isopropylene, based on a Deutsche Texaco process, and 2-methyl-2-butene are similar.

At the same time, the latter amount was split between the following sources (1) "Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin", (2) "Water, river", and (3) "Water, well. in ground"

exchanges.description: This value is estimated based on the heating requirements of a similar process. Specifically, this value represents the direct hydration of isopropanol, which was reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989). The value of steam input for the latter process is 12.65 MJ per kg. All in all, we assume that the heating requirements for the hydration of isopropylene, based on a Deutsche Texaco process, and 2-methyl-2-butene are similar.

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. References: Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
